Posts.Content: #32. You'll be fine - not just at the beginning but before op, again before chemo and before rads.  - Will I?  That's alright then.
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: Hi, I've just been diagnosed (yesterday) and am waiting for my date for surgery.  What a lot to take in and learn :(.  My tumour is just behind the nipple and the surgeon would like to remove it along with the tumour but I'd really like to hold on to it if possible.  Has anyone tried to keep the nipple?  I feel if I can keep it I'll still have part of myself, am I focusing too much on this?  I've been told I'll have sentinel node biopsy in the same surgery, followed by radiotherapy and tamoxifen.  I haven't been referred for MRI or CT or had blood tests - is this usual?  So sorry for so many questions but I'm finding searching through all the different postings confusing at this point.  I guess it'll start to make sense soon but I feel as though I have a thousand piece jigsaw in front of me!  Many thanks.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma.

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for you responses and I've been able to read through the information this morning and actually take it in.  Yesterday was a bit of a haze to say the least!   Thanks for the link to nipple reconstruction Karen,  I think I'd like to see what a nipple reconstruction looks like to help me make that decision so I've asked my nurse and she's going to find some clinical pics and a buddy for me. I guess I could Google but who knows what results I'll get from a 'tattooed nipple' search :). George and Jackie, thanks for the heads-up re possible changes to the treatment - I guess they can only plan for what they can see now which is the best case scenario.  I can't believe that today I'm hoping that I only have what I've been told so far.  I've spoken to the nurse about the MRI and they don't feel it's needed in my case.  Obviously I am now thinking  that every cough means it's spread to the lungs, every ache means it's gone to the bones but I need to stop that.  Reading what others have gone through puts that sort of imagining into perspective!  Lynned6, it's looks like I have what you've got, grade 2 and I hope I get the same results from the lymph nodes.  I'll look on FB to try and find some local groups (I've looked at Macmillam but there was nothing) my hospital is in Guildford which has quite a large cancer centre so I would hope there's something but I haven't been able to find anything yet.  Bev, it's very encouraging to see you (and Lynned6) have gone through so much and got through to the other side.  Interesting to hear you don't mind the loss of the nipple so much now.  I suppose if it comes down to being cancer free or keeping a cancerous nipple the choice is pretty clear! Thank you all for your responses and support and I'll try not to post at midnight again when my head is full of horrible thoughts.   Good luck and I hope everything goes well for you all.   L xxx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma.

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly i saw the article and intend to ask about this when I have my rad review on Wednesday (I have another 4 weeks of rads and have just started to pink up after rad #4).  It appears to be available on the NHS and trials have shown it's more effective than the usual E45 + Aloe.  My centre don't seem to give out any creams - I've been told to buy my own but I'm certainly going to ask for a prescription for this.   https://www.radiotherapytreatment.com/buy-r1-r2/    Lee x
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly Just to update you, I got a script for R1 & R2 from my doc today as I've had an allergic reaction to the lanolin in e45.  It has to be ordered in at the pharmacy so I've also got some medi honey - am now spoilt for choice! Boob is almost at the glow in the dark stage and I have to manoeuvre myself into a position to leave it outside the duvet at night.  Hopefully the R1 & R2 will help.  Lee
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Genny1312 Sorry somehow the reply I wrote earlier hasn't appeared.   Thanks for your positivity and support.   I think the test you refer to may be an Oncotype DX which is only available if you're HER2-? Im not sure I'd opt for chemo for an extra 3% because I have all sorts of other health issues but well done for making what was probably the hardest decision of your life.  What I'm learning is that no two situations are the same but if I have to have chemo I now accept it has to be.   I hope things continue to go well for you and your last session will soon be over.  Theres's light at the end of the tunnel :) Good luck Lee x
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Thanks weemaw, I'm slowly coming around to the idea that it's in my best interest to have chemo :(.  As with all of this, it takes time to sink in and accept what's happening  when you just want to close your eyes and ears and pretend it's not real.  Good to hear you're through to the other side (and with hair!!).  Good luck with your continuing treatment. Lee x
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the encouragement Jane.  It's good to hear it's not all bad, when you read the postings it does seem like everyone has lots of problems but I guess we don't post when we're doing well.  I'm over the moon about the baby and it really is a target to aim for :)  good luck with the hair and toenails !!
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Hi, I have been diagnosed with triple positive BC (ER+7, PR+8 and HER2+), path from WLE showed clear margins and clear lymph nodes.  I'm waiting to see the oncologist but my surgeon seems to think chemo will be required because of HER2+ involvement.   I feel this is overkill - does anyone have experience of triple positive and what have you done?  I really don't want to undergo chemo unless absolutely necessary :(  Would it be dangerous to refuse and just stick with radiotherapy and hormone treatment?   I can't believe that in just a few weeks I now know what these acronyms and figures mean, all this seemed like gobbledygook back in early March.   Thanks to to all on this great site.  Lee x
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Hi Maggiemay and Jane, were you both ER positive?    What a hard decision for you both to make and I admire you for going for chemo - it frightens the living daylights out of me.  My first grandchild is due in October and I cant bear the thought of being chemo ill when he/she arrives.  My son says he just wants me to be here to see the child grow up but I guess I want what I can't have and that's good health.  It always takes me a few sleeps before I can get my head around each new setback so I should be able to deal with this one eventually Take care Lee x
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Thanks Dreamthief.  I thought I'd got the hang of this but forgot to include my grade, it's 2.  My hospital doesn't seem to go in for staging so I don't have that figure.   I had got my head around needing surgery, radiotherapy and tamoxifen but they threw in  the chemo curveball when I went for my surgery path results and I was a bit shocked.  I've read a lot about HER2 in the last 24 hours including a scientific paper that concludes chemo is not that effective for HER2+, ER+ cancers http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305737214002102  Thanks for the heads up on the Predict tool - didn't know it existed.  Interestingly it only shows survival rates for me with hormone therapy and not chemo.   Maybe they won't want me to have it after all.  I have to stop second guessing but the waiting for the onco appt will be the hardest part - up to 4 weeks in this area.  Thanks again, much appreciated x Anyone out there with personal experience?
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Hi Trishell, Thanks and I do feel much better today. Onwards and upwards. I may well learn how to do the injections myself but it was such a pleasure having the original nurse come in each day to talk to.  the first cycle was always going to be a learning curve. Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Blackrabbit  i still have my hair as I'm only 9days in on my first TC.  I'm using the cold cap so I'm hoping to keep most of mine - I guess I'll find out fairly soon if it's working.   From what I've read from the other ladies the soreness eases once all the hair gone.  I'm sure one of them will give you a bit of advice on how to soothe it tonight .  A hugely emotional day for you but it's another thing you've achieved and one less hurdle to face.   Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Forgot to say Von, keep very hydrated especially for the first few days. cheers Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi all, 7days post first TC and what a roller coaster.  Started off really positive but developed a high temp on Friday - fortunately it didn't go over 38 so I didn't have to go in for an IV but I felt soooo bad for 3 days.  Woke up yesterday feeling better thinking it would be a good day but had intense back and chest pain, collapsed in the docs surgery and ended up in hospital last night.    No idea what or why, was treated as a suspected PE, then heart attack then fractured spine (I have osteo) - it was none of the above.  Today I'm fine and wondering what just happened.   A long shot - do any of you have the tummy injections and does it matter how they're injected?   I was fine with the first four but yesterday's nurse was in a hurry and just put the solution straight into the syringe and stabbed me.  The only other different thing yesterday was taking risedronate first thing.    All a bit of a mystery but I suppose I have to try and keep it together and move on.  My lowest point was having a bit of a cry this morning and having blood come out of my nose instead of snot.  Who'd thought you could miss snot?    Hope all the rest of you are doing well and sorry to report such a tale of woe.  Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Blackrabbit So sorry all your hair has gone :( and welcome to the club. I hope you'll feel better about it tomorrow, do you have a wig already or are you going to go the hat/scarf route?   Good luck with your second one tomorrow.  Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Two probably particularly stupid questions 1) I'm at the point in the cycle where I'm at my lowest immunity - can I go to the supermarket and mix with people?  Is it best to stay home for a few days?  2) The weather forecast is for a hot and sunny few days, is it ok to go out in the sun if wearing sun cream?   Thanks
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi ChrissieC, hope your T went well. I haven't had FEC, only T (plus C)  but even though I had bad days on my first cycle from days 3-10 it still wasn't as bad as I imagined and my good days have been relatively 'normal'.  I'm not sure if it gets worse with each cycle but I expect there will be some sort of cumulative effect. Bunglesabout, were your pains related to the bone marrow injections?  I think that's what made me feel worse.  I hope your next one goes better - you're right with the advice  to seek help as soon as any side effect becomes difficult.   Birty and Debbie, I'm booked in for a PICC line next week because my veins are in hiding but think I may insist they just keep stabbing me every time instead. Does anyone know if you have to be hooked to an IV  for Herceptin treatment?  This will go on for a year so I need to factor that into any decision I make.   Hope you're all having a decent day Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Day 17 post 1st cycle of T (+C) and after using the cold cap I'm finding my scalp quite tender today and am losing some hair :(  I hope it stops or slows down because I found I can cope with the cap quite well and intend to carry on unless it all goes.  Btw Nadjie most of my foo foo hair went yesterday too!  Good luck tomorrow Trish and thanks for the info re the PICC everyone. I'm not sure what I'll do next Wednesday but at least I'm a bit more informed now. Goodnight Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi ladies i haven't posted in a while but am awake and kicking after my second TC today with added Herceptin.  I guess the fatigue will hit during the day tomorrow. Suffering from yucky heartburn so can't lie down and have a belly the size of a whale because I'm not peeing but apart from that it went ok.   I feel stupid for saying this but I have been terribly down because of hair loss.  I tolerated the cold cap really well but by day 14 of the first cycle my hair was coming out in clumps and is now around 60% gone.  I had the cold cap again today but a lot of my hair came out when I took the cap off :(   I know so many of you ladies have faced this full on and shaved your head and accepted the inevitable but I m really struggling. My hair was fabulous, my one good feature and without it I feel my confidence has been stripped to nothing.  I've started wearing the wig but the soreness of my head and the itching make it uncomfortable so I'm actually pleased that I'll be mostly at home for the next week.  I did the Look Good Feel Better course last week and that helped for a day. I can't bear the thought it's going to take me years to get back my crowning glory and have no guarantee it'll ever be the same again.  I hope I've still got something to hang on to until the end - even if it's just a few strands of 'me'. How weird that this has become the biggest focal point when I had so many other side effects last time and am probably about to face them all again in the coming week    Oh dear, what a self indulgent rant, I blame it on the middle of the night and chemo day.    Hope you're all doing well and there are not too many nasties side effects out there. Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Thanks Nadjie i have coconut oil that I use for my mouth so I'll have a go with that. The soreness is a bit better today - I think the cold cap yesterday has cooled it down a bit.  I'lm also going to start experimenting with scarves, I have quite a few but have just never used them on my head!  Will certainly look for a headstrong workshop and really appreciate your support. Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Vonnie, I've just bought a nutribullet and ordered flaxseed, linseeds etc to add to the juices thinking this would be a good source of nutrition as I haven't had much of an appetite.   I didn't see this as a supplement but as a foodstuff. I didn't even think about asking if it was ok :(  I know you have to take the juices in small quantities at first and I think that's what I'll doand see how I feel.  Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Von I'm also on TC because of my heart.  I am due to have my second next Thursday.  Those steroids really do pump you up, I was awake for 24 hours before my first cycle but I really got a lot done in that time!  My experience of the set up for the first one was I was given 3 lots of anti sickness drugs which somehow calmed me down a bit then I was attached to a saline drip. I was given T first which took about 90 - 120 mins, had saline flushed through and then had the C injected slowly into the cannula.  I felt fine afterwards and for the first couple of days.   Days 3 - 10 weren't great. I had an elevated temp but not over 38 so I didn't go in to hospital. This may have been related to a sore throat I'd had in the previous week rather than the treatment. On the up side I didn't eat very much so managed to lose a couple of pounds. I was unlucky on day 10 with intense chest pain and did have  to go in for one night - I think they were overly cautious because of my history.  I underwent every test under the sun and was given the all clear and was fine the next day. This is not common and was specific to me.   From day 11 I have felt 'normal'. - I continue to get side effects but all are much more manageable than I expected.   I didn't drive on my bad days because I felt unwell but since then it's been life as normal except I'm not  mixing too much with lots of people as I really don't want any sort of infection. Unfortunately I can still operate a vacuum cleaner and do the washing! Good luck for tomorrow and let me know how you get on   Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Thanks Hevbojangles.  I had my son with me (no hubby) and felt so bad for him having to see me go through it all.  He's been an absolute rock through this but it's hard to watch your kid having to become the adult. (he's not exactly a child, he's 28 but he'll always be my little boy)  Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Thanks Chrissie, the good thing that I'm finding is that each blip I'm facing is intense but doesn't last for long.  lets hope the bad times ahead are few for all of us. Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Von, I haven't tried the nutribullet out just yet - waiting for the online shop to be delivered tomorrow.  Thats a good heads up re buying fresh and freezing - the amount of raspberries and strawberries I end up throwing out is criminal. I'm a bit worried about the extra calories tho'.   Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Chrissie, good news you still have hair, I'm sure it will help at the end of all this when we're trying to get back to who we were. My tender bit is on the crown so I'm really hoping I don't end up like Friar Tuck or Bill Bailey :) Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Karin & Trish, I had my second TC and first Herceptin last Thursday. No real problems so far, the only difference I noticed was my temp and pulse went down for a few days.  I only had to wait around for 2 hours afterwards - thank goodness it wasn't 6.  The main things are to be sure the Herceptin is at room temp and that it goes in slowly. I was a bit apprehensive beforehand so am a pretty relieved it went ok.   Karin, where is your pain?  I have pain in the tummy/back/pelvis with the bone marrow injections - is this what you're talking about? Apart from that I'm looking forward to getting passed day 9 so I can relax (that was the day I was hospitalised last time). Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Von i had a rash after my first TC - on my trunk, dark and spotty.  It didn't itch at all and I still have a bit of it through my second TC - they looked at it when I was hospitalised and weren't too concerned. Not sure if that's anything like you're experiencing?   If if it starts to itch or cause you problems call the on call the oncology registrar - I contact mine through the chemo helpline at my hospital.   Message me if you need any more detail.  Lee x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Steve, at the risk of sounding a complete dunce, where is The Room of which you speak?   Lee x
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Glad it's not just me   What with this and Victoria Derbyshire doing the cancer treatment is a doddle routine, I think I reached grumpy old bag boiling point! I checked the stats and there is no greater incidence of BC in UK towns and cities compared to rural areas.  It's marginally more prevalent in the most affluent but maybe because they get checked more?  Those in deprived areas have a lower incidence.  I will take a deeper breath when I read the next report - I just wish they wouldn't broadcast on the news as though it is fact.  We have enough to deal with without feeling it's somehow our fault.   Lee x
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Hi In the news today the latest 'findings' say that cancer is our own fault, related to our lifestyles and not bad luck after all.  Well, I have never been overweight, am vegetarian and hardly drink.  I did have a very stressful job and took HRT. I find it quite upsetting that, in addition to having an aggressive cancer, I'm now to be seen as bringing it upon myself.   How do others feel about this?  Am I just having a sensitive day? Lee x
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Hi Fran So sorry to hear the side effects you’re getting my Exemestane buddy.  I’ve been taking it for 4 weeks now.  I did get the runs for the first 2 weeks but that’s gone now and wasn’t too bad and I do get headaches but if I drink loads of water they seem to pass.  So far, for me, this is better than Tamoxifen which really affected my quality of life.   As was said by Helen, speak to your oncologist to find out how stopping could affect your long term survival rate so you can make an informed decision.  However, Tamoxifen may be something you could tolerate? (lots of people seem to get on well with it) or maybe try other brands of Exemestane (my first pack was Pfizer).  If you’re finding it too much to have to make this decision at this moment then perhaps postpone until radiotherapy is over.  You may feel more able to deal with it then.  All the best Lee
Posts.Title: Stopping homone therepy

Posts.Content: Hi Meeralax, I am about 2 weeks ahead of you after all the same treatment.  I feel I could have written your post as I feel exactly the same - lost. I've also been avoiding people recently because I can't stand being told how well I look and how I can now start getting back to 'normal'   In addition my boyfriend died suddenly in July and my first grandchild was born in October - talk about a mad roller coaster of emotions!   I'm sorry I don't have any real answers but know you're not alone feeling this way.  One thing that has helped me was meeting with a group of breast cancer survivors last week - it helped to see that people do move on, hair grows back and lives can be rebuilt.  I'm not sure what area you're in but if you're anywhere near Surrey message me and I can give you details or meet up for a moan.  Also I do still feel the extreme tiredness is not quite as bad as it was two weeks ago when I finished rads. Good luck and big hugs  Lee x
Posts.Title: Getting Harder

Posts.Content: Hi Margym,  I had my op 5 weeks ago and had a build up of blood and fluid in the breast (haematoma and seroma).   My breast had a very bruised appearance which looked almost like a port wine stain in places and was sore and heavy.  i did start to bleed from the scar from the end of week 2 and had to go back several times for the blood to be removed (not as bad as it sounds).  5 weeks on I'm not in pain but still have bruising, a haematoma that can't now be aspirated which I have been told will absorb into my body over the next few weeks/months.   I'm worried that you say yours is very painful - mine was sore and uncomfortable but not as painful as the lymph area under my armpit.  If your breast feels hot or you get a fever then call your BC nurse immediately in case of infection.  If your BC nurse is as useless as mine it may be worth seeing your GP for reassurance if you still have a while before your follow-up with the surgeon.   Good luck and hope you feel better soon  Lee x
Posts.Title: painful bruising after op

Posts.Content: Thanks for arranging this Karen - I strongly recommend they do this in other areas if possible.    It was lovely to meet up and I hope we get to do it again. It was good to share experiences and have a proper laugh with you all.  Lee x
Posts.Title: Meet up Farnham / Guildford area

Posts.Content: I’m in
Posts.Title: Meet up Farnham / Guildford area

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, is this happening or are people still trying to catch up after Christmas? I’ll be available on Saturday afternoon if you’ve managed to drum up a group. Can you PM me details if it’s to go ahead. Cheers Lee
Posts.Title: Meet up Farnham / Guildford area

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, I’m looking forward to the meet up on the 31st.  Would it be ok if I bring a lovely lady (Rosemary) who I met at a pink ribbon Pilates class?  She’s not on the Macmillan site but went through her treatment at RSCH like most of us.   See you next week  Lee x
Posts.Title: Meet up Farnham / Guildford area
